factoid: Héloïse sent a Key to the Mysteries to Princess Mary.
The narrator looked at the Key to the Mysteries.
The narrator told Princess Mary to take the Key.
The narrator told Princess Mary to go.
The narrator patted Princess Mary on the shoulder.
The narrator closed the door after Princess Mary.
Princess Mary went back to her room.
Princess Mary had a sad, scared expression that rarely left Princess Mary.
Princess Mary's face was plain and sickly.
Princess Mary sat down at her writing table.
The writing table had miniature portraits on it.
The writing table was littered with books and papers.
Princess Mary's father was tidy.
Princess Mary was untidy.
Princess Mary put down the geometry book.
Princess Mary broke the seal of her letter.
The letter was from Julie Karágina.
Julie Karágina was Princess Mary's most intimate friend from childhood.
Julie Karágina had been at the Rostóvs’ name-day party.
Julie Karágina wrote in French.
Julie Karágina addressed Princess Mary as "Dear and precious Friend".
Julie Karágina said separation is terrible and frightful.
Julie Karágina said half Julie Karágina's life and half Julie Karágina's happiness are wrapped up in Princess Mary.
Julie Karágina said their hearts are united by indissoluble bonds.
Julie Karágina said Julie Karágina's heart rebels against fate.
Julie Karágina said Julie Karágina cannot overcome a secret sorrow since they part.
Julie Karágina wondered why they are not together as they were last summer.
Julie Karágina remembered their big study on the blue sofa.
Julie Karágina remembered the confidential sofa.
Julie Karágina wondered why Julie Karágina cannot now draw fresh moral strength from Princess Mary's look.
Julie Karágina described Princess Mary's look as gentle, calm, and penetrating.
Princess Mary sighed after reading the letter.
Princess Mary glanced into the mirror on her right.
The mirror reflected a weak, ungraceful figure and thin face.
Princess Mary's eyes were always sad.
Princess Mary's eyes looked with particular hopelessness at Princess Mary's reflection.
Princess Mary thought "She flatters me."
Princess Mary turned away from the mirror.
Princess Mary continued to read.
Julie Karágina did not flatter Princess Mary.
Princess Mary's eyes were large, deep, and luminous.
Princess Mary's eyes radiated shafts of warm light at times.
Princess Mary's eyes were beautiful.
Princess Mary's eyes gave Princess Mary an attraction more powerful than beauty.
Princess Mary never saw the beautiful expression of Princess Mary's own eyes when she was not thinking of herself.
Princess Mary's face assumed a forced unnatural expression when she looked in a glass.
Julie Karágina wrote that all Moscow talks were about war.
Julie Karágina said one of Julie Karágina's two brothers is abroad.
Julie Karágina said the other brother of Julie Karágina is with the Guards.
Julie Karágina said the Guards are starting a march to the frontier.
Julie Karágina said the Emperor has left Petersburg.
Julie Karágina said the Emperor intends to expose his precious person to chances of war.
Julie Karágina said God grant that the Corsican monster destroying the peace of Europe may be overthrown by the angel.
Julie Karágina said the angel has pleased the Almighty to give them as sovereign.
Julie Karágina said the war deprived Julie Karágina of one of the associations nearest Julie Karágina's heart.
Julie Karágina said the association was young Nicholas Rostóv.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv could not bear to remain inactive.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv left the university to join the army.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv's departure for the army was a great grief.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv is noble-minded.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv is full of real youthfulness.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv is frank.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv has much heart.
Julie Karágina said Nicholas Rostóv is pure and poetic.
Julie Karágina said their relations were one of the sweetest comforts to Julie Karágina's heart.
Julie Karágina said Julie Karágina will tell Princess Mary about their parting.
Julie Karágina said Julie Karágina's parting is still too fresh.
Julie Karágina said Princess Mary is happy not to know these joys and sorrows.
Julie Karágina said Princess Mary is fortunate.
Julie Karágina said the joys and sorrows are generally stronger.
Julie Karágina said Count Nicholas is too young to be more to Julie Karágina than a friend.
Julie Karágina said the sweet friendship was what Julie Karágina's heart needed.
Julie Karágina said the chief news was the death of old Count Bezúkhov and his inheritance.
Julie Karágina said the three princesses received very little.
Julie Karágina said Prince Vasíli received nothing.
Julie Karágina said Monsieur Pierre inherited all the property.
Julie Karágina said Monsieur Pierre was recognized as legitimate.
Julie Karágina said Monsieur Pierre is now Count Bezúkhov.
Julie Karágina said Monsieur Pierre possesses the finest fortune in Russia.
Julie Karágina said Prince Vasíli played a very despicable part in this affair.
Julie Karágina said Prince Vasíli returned to Petersburg quite crestfallen.
